awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Proposal for a SUMMIT to Plan a Conference Workshop for Minoritized Geoscientists
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to host a four-day summit with fifteen leaders from Geoscience organizations with a demonstrated interest in improving belonging, accessibility, justice, equity, diversity, and inclusivity (BeAJEDI). The summit will provide these leaders with opportunities to share successful strategies for improving BeAJEDI in Geoscience. Leaders at the summit will design a conference where ~100-300 Geoscientists  network, present their research, and share successful strategies for improving BeAJEDI in Geoscience. The summit will thus begin the process of increasing interagency and interpersonal sharing, design, and refinement of the strategies used to strengthen BeAJEDI in Geoscience.

The main goal of this project is to host a four-day summit with 15 leaders from the largest and or influential Geoscience organizations with a demonstrated interest in improving belonging, accessibility, justice, equity, diversity, and inclusivity (BeAJEDI) in Geoscience. Summit participants will collaboratively design a conference workshop while sharing successful strategies for improving BeAJEDI for Geoscientists of Color. This designed workshop will be primarily attended by Geoscientists and will allow attendees to present research and network. The workshop will also include surveying and interviewing attendees to collect information that are germane for successfully recruiting and retaining People of Color within Geoscience. The questions that the surveys and interviews seek to answer are:

1.	What attracts People of Color to Geoscience?
2.	What are the experiences of Geoscientists of Color?
3.	What do full belonging, accessibility, justice, equity, diversity, and inclusivity look like to Geoscientists of Color? 

Alongside developing a novel method of answering the questions listed above, this project's broader impacts are strengthened by including a mentorship component. The summit will pair early-career researchers interested in BeAJEDI issues with established and experienced individuals. The early-career researchers will gain conference proposal writing experience while expanding their network.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

inst.inst_name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

por.por_cntn:
Overview. The goal of this funded planning grant project was to develop a conference that aims to answer the following questions: 1) What attracts minoritized individuals to Geoscience, 2) What are the experiences of minoritized geoscientists, and 3) What do full belonging, accessibility, justice, equity, diversity, and inclusivity (BAJEDI) look like to racially minoritized geoscientists? Alongside this, the conference should also serve as a place for diverse geoscientists to network and share their science, in their way. Fifteen geoscientists attended a summit at Scripps Institution of Oceanography to collaboratively develop the conference plans. We describe the developed plans below. 

Conference Programming. reSURGE, the name we give to the future conference, would take place over 6 days, where Day 1 will be designated for participants to travel to the conference site and participate in a plenary session to introduce participants to the conference and the goals of the reSURGE conference. Days 2-4 will be split into a morning and afternoon session. During the morning session, participants will participate in a plenary session that focuses on one of the three focus questions of reSURGE and will follow with guided group discussions to compile data that can be analyzed post-conference to understand the experiences of GoC within the Geosciences. The afternoon sessions will be the scientific portion of the conference, where participants are encouraged to share their science, their way. We will encourage participants to deliver their presentations (both oral and poster) in a way that elevates their presentation style and their culture and practices. A cultural dinner reception will be held after the afternoon session and will be an opportunity for participants to connect and build a sense of community amongst themselves. Day 5 will follow the structure of days 2-4, except that this day will involve the participation of allies/accomplices and will involve discussing the compilation and implementation of anti-racist policies at the institutions of the participants. Day 6 is a half-day focused on community outreach activities in which both GoC and allies/accomplices can participate.

Participation. A solicitation to attend the conference will be sent out several months in advance, and we will select approximately 100 participants to participate in the conference. We advise that there be a rubric on the selection of participants who are invited to attend the conference. We will encourage all to apply, and especially encourage participants who are historically excluded in Geoscience and those who actively engaging in BAJEDI-related work outside of just participating in the conference.

Data Collection, Analysis, and Dissemination. A team of social scientists and geoscientists will work together to formulate pre-, during, and post-conference surveys to collect qualitative and quantitative data from participants related to the three focus questions of reSURGE. The data will be analyzed after the conference and compiled into a post-conference report. The results of these surveys will serve as a guide for future conference focus questions and address the current needs of the GoC community.

Budget and Justification. We would request sufficient funding to support all who are selected to participate in the conference, including travel, accommodation, meals, and funds for child/dependent care. Additional funding for conference venue-related costs and conference management will be needed to ensure that the conference is successful.

Duration and Sustainability. We will partner with other geoscience conferences (i.e., AGU, GSA, etc.) to help incorporate the gained knowledge from the conference and experience into their infrastructure to support GoC in the future. 

Intellectual Merit. Gaining knowledge about the fundamental questions of reSURGE is crucial for understanding the recruitment and retention (or lack thereof) of GoC in the Geosciences and broader STEM fields. Current and former GoC will provide insight into the current landscape of BAJEDI within the Geosciences across the different and unique intersectionalities within the Geosciences. The conversations and answers revolving around these questions will help guide national efforts to transform the research enterprise within Geosciences. The knowledge gained through reSURGE will be applicable and valuable to STEM fields outside of Geosciences.

Broader Impacts. The reSURGE conference would take place in a location within the United States that fits at least one of the following criteria: 1) the location is home to one or more HBCUs/MSIs/TCs, and 2) the location is working to address a relevant environmental justice issue within the community. The conference will engage with local environmental justice workers and faculty and students for the surrounding HBCUs/MSIs/TCs and invite them to participate in the scientific sessions of the conference. The conference will work together with local small businesses to service the conference, supporting the local economy. The conference will reach out to local community members for a morning outreach activity that will engage locals of all ages and backgrounds with the work of GoC and other participants in the conference.
